header.title: The Scroll of Set Table of Contents (Through Volume XXV, 1999)

central_thesis: This compilation of 'The Scroll of Set' articles serves as the primary internal publication for the Temple of Set, meticulously documenting the ongoing development and articulation of Setian philosophy, operative magical practices, administrative affairs, and community discussions from its founding in 1975 through 1999. It reflects the organization's core tenets of individual self-deification (Xeper) and the exploration of the Left-Hand Path, offering both theoretical exposition and practical guidance for its members.

structure_content.summary: This section compiles articles elucidating the fundamental philosophical underpinnings of the Temple of Set. Recurring themes include the nature of Set, the concept of Xeper (self-creation/becoming), the distinction between Setianism and traditional Satanism, the Left-Hand Path, and the subjective universe. It features a wide range of essays, aphorisms, and theoretical discussions by prominent Setian thinkers, often contrasting Setian views with other esoteric and philosophical traditions. Topics like the 'Æon of Set', 'Magic and the Law of Karma', and 'Individualistic Collectivism' highlight the intellectual exploration central to the Temple's ethos.

This category focuses on the practical application of Setian principles through ritual and magical workings. Articles cover diverse aspects, including general ritual theory, specific pylon workings (e.g., Bubastis Pylon, Set-Amentet Pylon, Gates of Hell Pylon), the use of magical tools, and discussions on phenomena like telepathy and astral projection. Descriptions range from 'Physiology in the Ritual Chamber' to 'Implementing Black Magic' and 'Operant Magic of Runa', providing insights into the mechanics, purpose, and experiences of magical practice within the Setian system. It includes instructions, reports, and discussions aimed at guiding practitioners.

This part covers the organizational structure, administrative announcements, and community life of the Temple of Set. It includes reports from 'Council of Nine' meetings, updates on 'National Conclaves', information about regional 'Pylons', membership recognitions, and general notices to the membership. Articles like 'Temple of Set Officials', 'New Administrative Systems', and 'Executive Director Announcements' reflect the internal governance and efforts to foster a cohesive and active Setian community. This section also serves as a historical record of the Temple's growth and operational evolution.

This section features biographical profiles of key Setian figures (e.g., 'Biography: Margaret Wendall IV°'), along with reviews of books, films, and other media relevant to Setian interests or occultism at large. It also includes personal 'Set-Experiences' and 'Forum' discussions, offering individual perspectives and fostering dialogue among members. Reviews like 'Dogs of War, Supernature', 'The Art of Loving', or 'Star Wars' demonstrate the intellectual engagement and cultural interests of the Setian community, often interpreting popular culture through an esoteric lens.

key_concepts.definition: The core Setian concept of self-deification or self-creation, meaning 'I have come into being.' It represents the ongoing process of individual becoming, perpetual advancement, and the realization of one's unique potential, often through the application of magical will.

The philosophical and magical system practiced by the Temple of Set, focused on the adoration and emulation of Set as a symbol of the Black Flame — the unique, individual consciousness inherent in each being. It emphasizes individualism, self-mastery, and the exploration of the Left-Hand Path.

Within the Setian context, Black Magic is understood as the application of will towards the exaltation and realization of the individual self (the Black Flame), distinct from practices aimed at collective good or traditional 'evil.' It is operative magic directed towards personal transformation and power.

A local group or chapter of the Temple of Set, serving as a hub for members to gather, study, and engage in collaborative magical workings and philosophical discussions. Pylons are often named after Setian or Egyptian deities/concepts (e.g., Bubastis Pylon, Set-Amentet Pylon).

A hierarchical system within the Temple of Set indicating a member's level of advancement, knowledge, and magical attainment. These degrees ('Initiate', 'Adept', 'Priest/Priestess', 'Magister/Magistra', 'Magus/Magistra Templi', 'Setian') signify a progression in understanding and applying Setian philosophy and operative magic.

key_concepts.term: The Book of Coming Forth by Night
key_concepts.definition: A foundational text within the Temple of Set, often presented as a Setian counterpoint or reinterpretation of the Egyptian Book of the Dead. It is central to understanding Setian philosophy and practices.

A historical and magical epoch identified by the Temple of Set, representing a current phase of human consciousness and magical possibility, particularly in contrast to prior Æons (e.g., Isis, Osiris, Horus). It signifies a time ripe for individual self-realization through Setian principles.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined across these articles is fundamentally centered on individual self-deification through 'Xeper,' an ongoing process of self-creation and personal evolution. This is achieved through intellectual rigor, philosophical exploration, and the active application of operative magic. The system encourages practitioners to cultivate their unique consciousness ('Black Flame'), develop personal power, and reshape their reality in accordance with their will. Rituals, pylon workings, and the study of Setian texts are key components for achieving these transformative goals.
tools: Tarot (as a divinatory and magical tool)
rituals: Pylon Workings (e.g., Draconis Pylon Ritual, Set-Amentet Pylon Ritual, Gates of Hell Pylon)
Rite for the Festival of Bubastis
The Book of Coming Forth by Night (as a ritual text/framework)

critical_analysis.relevance: This collection of 'The Scroll of Set' is of significant relevance for academics and practitioners studying modern Western Esotericism and new religious movements, particularly those interested in the Left-Hand Path and Setianism. It provides an invaluable primary source for understanding the internal development, philosophical evolution, and practical magical emphasis of the Temple of Set over a quarter-century. For practitioners, it offers a deep dive into the theoretical and operative aspects of Setian magic, directly from its authoritative voices, facilitating a deeper engagement with the system of Xeper.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is the membership of the Temple of Set, from initiates to high-degree members, seeking to deepen their understanding and practice of Setian philosophy and magic. Secondarily, it serves scholars and researchers in religious studies, sociology of religion, and occult studies, offering a unique window into the inner workings and public articulations of a contemporary esoteric organization. Individuals interested in the Left-Hand Path, Chaos Magic, and philosophical Satanism may also find this compilation highly relevant.
